required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Autologous Human Schwann Cells in Peripheral Nerve Repair
clinical_study.official_title: The Safety and Efficacy of Autologous Human Schwann Cell (ahSC) Augmentation of Nerve Autografts After Severe Peripheral Nerve Injury (PNI)

collaborator.agency: The Miami Project to Cure Paralysis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the safety of autologous human Schwann cell (ahSC) augmentation of nerve autograft repair in participants with severe peripheral nerve injury (PNI). For humans with acute severe PNI, the hypothesis is that augmentation of nerve autograft repair with ahSCs can potentially enhance axonal regeneration and myelin repair and thus improve functional recovery.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with reported adverse events (AEs)
primary_outcome.description: The number of participants with reported AEs will be evaluated to assess safety. Using CTCAE v4.0 grading scale, all AEs that are Grade 3 or higher with treating physician's attribution of probable or definite relation to intervention will be included.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with reported cell product culture test failure
primary_outcome.description: Using sterility testing, the number of participants with reported cell product culture test failure will be evaluated.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in muscle strength scale grade of affected limb muscles
primary_outcome.description: The Medical Research Council (MRC) scale for muscle strength grades muscle power on a scale of 0 to 5 in relation to the maximum expected for that muscle.

primary_outcome.measure: Sensory recovery scale grade of affected dermatomes
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of pin-prick and two point discrimination in areas previously anesthetic in the distal distribution of the nerve injury.

The Douleur Neuropathique 4 (DN4) questionnaire estimates the probability of neuropathic pain, based on 10 items. Seven items related to pain quality are based on an interview and 3 items are based on clinical examination.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in pain characteristics (location, intensity, and description)
primary_outcome.description: Assessed by a pain diagram which identifies areas of pain with descriptors. An intensity scale from 0 (no pain) to 10 (most intense pain imaginable) is used to rate the overall intensity of pain at the time of assessment.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with reported tumorigenesis or unexpected changes in nerve structure
primary_outcome.description: Tumorigenesis and/or unexpected changes in the nerve structure will be determined by evaluation of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in muscle strength scale grade of affected limb muscles
secondary_outcome.description: The Medical Research Council (MRC) scale for muscle strength grades muscle power on a scale of 0 to 5 in relation to the maximum expected for that muscle.

secondary_outcome.measure: Sensory recovery scale grade of affected dermatomes
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of pin-prick and two point discrimination in areas previously anesthetic in the distal distribution of the nerve injury.

The Douleur Neuropathique 4 (DN4) questionnaire estimates the probability of neuropathic pain, based on 10 items. Seven items related to pain quality are based on an interview and 3 items are based on clinical examination.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in pain characteristics (location, intensity, and description)
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed by a pain diagram which identifies areas of pain with descriptors. An intensity scale from 0 (no pain) to 10 (most intense pain imaginable) is used to rate the overall intensity of pain at the time of assessment.
Ultrasound will be used to assess nerve-graft continuity.

arm_group.description: All participants will receive autologous human Schwann cells harvested from their own sural nerve.

intervention.description: Schwann cells harvested from the sural nerve and debrided, injured sciatic nerve of the participant will be autologously transplanted along sural nerve autografts wrapped in a collagen matrix
